JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Mark Villiger;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Renate Jaeger;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: The applicant , Mr. PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by PERSON , former Representative of GPE at ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant set up a deal with a certain PERSON ( “ the debtor ” ) : CARDINAL United States dollars ( ORG ) for a ORG car . The debtor took the applicant ’s money but never handed the car over to the applicant .
The applicant lodged a civil action against PERSON DATE ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) ordered that PERSON pay the applicant MONEY ( RUB ) . The judgment became binding on DATE .
On DATE a bailiff of GPE ( “ the bailiff ” ) opened enforcement proceedings .
The parties disagree as to the subsequent events DATE .
According to the applicant , the bailiff was inactive throughout this period and later forged enquiries to a bank and ORG backdated to DATE .

According to the Government , the bailiff took certain steps aimed at enforcing the judgment . On DATE the bailiff issued a charging order in respect of the debtor ’s cars , then had it transferred to FAC DATE . On DATE the debtor ’s garage was attached . On DATE the bailiff checked the state of the debtor ’s possessions . On DATE the bailiff drew up an inventory of the debtor ’s movable assets . DATE and DATE the enforcement proceedings were transferred to LOC service . The latter found that none of the debtor ’s property remained in LOC , so the enforcement proceedings were transferred back to LOC .
Further events are not disputed by the parties .

In DATE the bailiff attached part of a flat jointly owned by the debtor and his former wife , instructed ORG to impound the debtor ’s ORG car , if it could be located , made enquiries about the debtor ’s place of work and issued an order to retain CARDINAL of the debtor ’s salary every month for the benefit of the applicant , and suggested that the applicant accept the spare parts of a disassembled ORG car discovered in the debtor ’s attached garage as part satisfaction of the debt .

In DATE the debtor was asked by the bailiff to bring his ORG and PERSON cars to the bailiffs’ office , but failed to do so . In DATE the debtor , twice fined by the bailiff for failure to hand over his property , told the bailiff that he had sold the ORG in DATE to ORG . , and that the PERSON had been sold DATE , in DATE . By a judgment of DATE , which became binding on DATE , ORG confirmed that the debtor was still the legal owner of the ORG and that therefore the attachment of the vehicle was legal . As the ORG could not be located , the bailiffs conducted a search for it . Having yielded no results , the search was discontinued in DATE .

Some of the debtor ’s assets were not liable to seizure because the property was jointly owned by the debtor and his ex - wife , so the applicant brought a court action seeking division of their common assets . By a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , which became binding on DATE , ORG determined how the property in question was to be divided . According to the judgment , the debtor received in property a part of the flat and the garage , whereas the PERSON and the disassembled ORG acquired in the course of the marriage and registered at FAC in the debtor ’s name were given to the debtor ’s ex - wife .
By a decision of DATE ORG confirmed in the final instance that the debtor ’s part of the flat was not liable to seizure because it was the only home he had .
On DATE the debtor ’s garage , for which no bids had been made at auction , was given to the applicant .
On CARDINAL DATE the bailiff closed the enforcement proceedings . The applicant continued to receive DATE payments held back from the debtor ’s salary .
In the meantime , the applicant sued ORG for inflationary losses supposedly caused by the GPE inactivity during the enforcement of the judgment .
On DATE ORG granted the applicant ’s claim , but on DATE that decision was quashed on appeal and the matter was remitted for fresh examination before a first - instance court .

On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s claim in full . It held , inter alia , that , although the bailiffs had failed on several occasions to respect the procedural time - limits , there was no causal link between the bailiffs’ conduct and the alleged losses . On DATE ORG upheld the above decision on appeal .

LAW of the NORP federal law “ On Enforcement Procedure ” ( Law no . CARDINAL of DATE ) provides that a search for a debtor ’s missing property must be conducted by a bailiff if paid for in advance by a creditor . The creditor shall have the right to recover the incurred expenses from the debtor .

LAW same law provides for certain measures which a bailiff may take when private persons or public officials fail to comply with lawful orders , provide false information about a debtor ’s income and financial status , do not inform a bailiff about the debtor ’s dismissal from work , a change of the debtor ’s places of work or residence or when they do not respond to the bailiff ’s summonses . These measures include a fine of CARDINAL minimum wages , escorting a defaulting party by force to a place where enforcement actions are performed and institution of criminal proceedings .
